S5.T1.caption:
Table 1: Results of the federated navigation agents when not attacked and attacked on R2R [2] and RxR [16]. By default, FedAvg is utilized as the aggragation rule. The much higher ASR results indicate that the backdoor attack is successfully implanted.
Moreover, models with and without attack achieve similar navigation results, showing that the NAW attack is unnoticeable in FL.

references:
NAW successfully implants the backdoor into the global model. 
In Table 1, we report the results on R2R and RxR datasets.
First, comparing navigation metrics, the models trained with and without NAW have nearly the same performance, showing that the backdoor can be implanted without hurting the validation performance and thus is unnoticeable. However, Badnets has a significant drop in performance. It does not meet the basic requirement of the backdoor attack and shows its infeasibility, which verifies our concern.
Second, comparing the Attach Success Rate (ASR), we can observe that models trained with the NAW attack have a much higher ASR than unattacked, implying that the global agent has a very high probability of selecting the navigable viewpoints with the trigger. While not meeting the backdoor attack requirement, Badnets has the highest ASR. This may be because its trigger is a fixed pattern added to the image input, which could be easily recognized by the model.

Fidelity means that the method should not sacrifice the performance of the global model when there is no attack, taking the performance of the model of FedAvg as the reference standard. According to the results in Table 1 and Table 2, our PBA method performs similarly to FedAvg on seen and unseen environments, achieving the fidelity goal.
It demonstrates that the prompt added before the attention layer does not affect the model convergence and performance.
Compared to other defense methods, however, some of them dramatically hurt the performance. For instance, in Table 2, when applying FedCLIP-ViL on R2R, FLTrust performs much worse than FedAvg with an average of 25.6% SR and 21.2% SR drop on seen and unseen environments respectively. Median hurts the performance about 7.9% SR gap.

Fidelity means that the method should not sacrifice the performance of the global model when there is no attack, taking the performance of the model of FedAvg as the reference standard. According to the results in Table 1 and Table 2, our PBA method performs similarly to FedAvg on seen and unseen environments, achieving the fidelity goal.
It demonstrates that the prompt added before the attention layer does not affect the model convergence and performance.

Methods Val-Seen Val-Unseen

No Attack 0.08 0.07 0.05 0.05
\hdashlineFedAvg 0.71 0.87 0.68 0.85

Trim-Mean 0.76 0.86 0.74 0.84

references:
Robustness means that the ASR of the server model should be as low as possible.
In Table 3 and 4, PBA gets the lowest ASR on different models under both seen and unseen environments of R2R and RxR.
On the contrary, some defense methods even exacerbate the model under attack. For example, PBA has the same selection rule as MultiKrum. However, MultiKrum utilizes the Euclidean distance of all model parameters to select benign clients. It turns out to get higher ASR than FedAvg, which indicates that it can not tell the difference between malicious and benign clients. Both MultiKrum and Bulyan filter the “malicious” clients they think, and use less number of clients for aggregation. It increases the weights of malicious clients during aggregation and then the probability of being attacked if they are wrongly judged, which unfortunately is exactly the case here.

references: We compare and evaluate PBA with other defense methods from three aspects,
Fidelity
Robustness
, and
Efficiency
Fidelity

means that the method should not sacrifice the performance of the global model when there is no attack, taking the performance of the model of FedAvg as the reference standard. According to the results in Table
and Table

, our PBA method performs similarly to FedAvg on seen and unseen environments, achieving the fidelity goal.
It demonstrates that the prompt added before the attention layer does not affect the model convergence and performance.
Compared to other defense methods, however, some of them dramatically hurt the performance. For instance, in Table

, when applying FedCLIP-ViL on R2R, FLTrust performs much worse than FedAvg with an average of 25.6% SR and 21.2% SR drop on seen and unseen environments respectively. Median hurts the performance about 7.9% SR gap.
Robustness

means that the ASR of the server model should be as low as possible.
In Table
and

, PBA gets the lowest ASR on different models under both seen and unseen environments of R2R and RxR.
On the contrary, some defense methods even exacerbate the model under attack. For example, PBA has the same selection rule as MultiKrum. However, MultiKrum utilizes the Euclidean distance of all model parameters to select benign clients. It turns out to get higher ASR than FedAvg, which indicates that it can not tell the difference between malicious and benign clients. Both MultiKrum and Bulyan filter the “malicious” clients they think, and use less number of clients for aggregation. It increases the weights of malicious clients during aggregation and then the probability of being attacked if they are wrongly judged, which unfortunately is exactly the case here.
Efficiency

means the method should not incur excessive extra computation and communication overhead. PBA only needs extra computation from local prompts (two 1-Dimensional vectors) for backdoor defense compared with normal FL, while the extra computation of the former methods involves all parameters of the model during aggregation.

Impact of prompt added before attention layer.
We introduce two variants of our attack methods, to further explore the impact of special utilization of prompt in PBA .
PBA-Input
: in most previous works, the prompt is added to the input embedding

, rather than the middle position before the attention layer in PBA . In light of this, we apply the prompts in input visual features and language features and calculate the similarity the same as PBA .
PBA-Param
: as the alignment variance is represented in the attention layer, we directly use the parameters of the attention layer to calculate the similarity of clients.
Fig.
shows the results of PBA and two variants on R2R unseen environments. (1) Directly using the parameters of the attention layer for evaluation is not effective, as illustrated in Sec.

. It achieves a high ASR on both models in R2R unseen environments. (2) The prompt position matters. PBA performs better than PBA -Input about 20% ASR on CLIP-ViL. Putting prompt right before the attention layer can better capture the alignment difference.
